Award.AwardTitle: The transport and accumulation of pyrogenic black carbon in recently burned watersheds and implications for water quality
Award.AbstractNarration:
The intensity and frequency of forest fires have increased since the 1950s and are predicted to continue to increase as a result of past fire management strategies, climate change, and shifts in land use. Black carbon (BC), in the form of soot and char, is generated by incomplete combustion of organic matter and is transported and re-deposited throughout downstream valleys and waterways by post-wildfire rainfall and flood events. Black carbon from wildfires has the potential for both negative and positive impacts on water quality. In the short term, for example, it may foul drinking water supplies and generate of anoxic conditions that are harmful to aquatic life. But the BC deposits produced on the landscape may act as carbon sinks and may sequester significant quantities of contaminants and heavy metals through sorption. This project will study the impacts of two recent wildfires in northern New Mexico with the goal of understanding the transport, accumulation, and residence times of BC in post-wildfire watersheds, as well as the environmental significance of these BC deposits. Black carbon will be measured in soils within burned areas, downstream of burns, and in areas unaffected by wildfires. Samples will be taken before and after two summer monsoon seasons, when mobilization is expected to occur, in order to understand transport and accumulation rates. Laboratory analysis will measure the amount of several heavy metals and burn-byproduct contaminants contained within the soil samples, and what percentage is held within the BC component of the soils. Further analysis will quantify the maximum capacity of the BC in the soils to sorb out and sequester these contaminants.

Black carbon is important to consider for at least three reasons: global carbon cycling, contaminant sequestration, and soil fertility. BC has traditionally been viewed as a chemically stable form of carbon, with suggestions that the addition of BC to soils as an amendment could serve as a carbon sink. Recent work, however, has found that BC is removed from the soil more rapidly than previously thought. Researchers have found significant quantities of BC dissolved in river water, which may mean that water percolating through the soil dissolves out some BC. Erosion and transport of BC-containing sediment is an additional way by which BC may be removed from soils, and this mechanism has received much less attention. This work will contribute to quantification of this poorly understood component of the carbon cycle. The findings are anticipated to be particularly relevant in areas that utilize fire-prone forest watersheds as a source of drinking water, which is the case for most of the southwestern US. The presence of black carbon in the soils of watersheds that are municipal water sources may provide an additional buffer to contamination risks. The results will also assist managers in developing post-fire recovery plans and may also be useful for ecological risk assessment following chemical spills. This work will support the training of two hydrologists at the MS level and provide a research experience for one undergraduate from New Mexico Institute of Mining and Technology, a Hispanic serving institution.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The goal of this research was to better understand how fire-derived black carbon (burn byproducts such as ash, soot, and char) is moved around the landscape following a wildfire. Black carbon is important because the surfaces of black carbon particles have physical and chemical properties that cause some contaminants to attach themselves, essentially sequestering them from transport in groundwater. Therefore locations where black carbon accumulates after a fire may serve as a filter for water flowing through the soils. It is also important to understand how much black carbon is retained in a burned watershed following the fire because this carbon can remain chemically stable in the soil for hundreds of years, reducing the amount of carbon present in the atmosphere.

The study had two parts, each of which was conducted by a hydrology graduate student studying at New Mexico Tech. First, the black carbon content of soils was measured at a variety of sites with different fire histories, all in the Jemez Mountains of New Mexico. A set of samples was collected from a 1-year-old fire scar, a 3-year-old fire scar, and a watershed that had not burned in at least 70 years. Additionally, soil samples were collected at the same points before and after a wildfire burned a watershed that had previously been studied. Black carbon contents were compared across time, space, and in different parts of the landscape (hillslopes, floodplains, landslide deposits). In this first part of the study we determined that (1) black carbon measurably increased following fire, especially in the upper layer of the soil; (2) older fire scars had less black carbon in the surface layer than more recent fires; (3) black carbon on floodplains increased following the storm events of the 2013 monsoon season; (4) some north-facing hillslopes experienced measureable down-slope movement of black carbon during monsoon season, but this was not observed on south-facing hillslopes; (5) during the fire for which we had pre- and post-fire soil samples, differences in black carbon content between neighboring slopes and different soil layers were erased, leaving a relatively homogenous layer of black carbon across the burn scar; and (6) in spite of this, variability at individual points on a single hillslope increased, because individual plants leave clusters of black carbon where they burn. 

The second part of the study tested the ability of black carbon to sequester two heavy metals that naturally occur in the study area, arsenic and chromium, by causing the dissolved elements to sorb, or stick, onto their surfaces. We used soils collected from near the burns studied in the first part, and char collected from burned logs within the fire perimeter. We mixed low concentration solutions of arsenic and chromium, similar to what may occur naturally, with the soils and with mixtures of soil and char. We found that when we mixed additional black carbon into the soils, the arsenic sorbed out of solution faster, but the same total amount was removed after a few days when equilibrium was reached. In contrast, 30% more chromium was sorbed out of solution when we added 5% extra black carbon by mass to our soil samples. Interestingly, the greatest increase in sorption appeared to occur for the first bit of black carbon added; there were diminishing returns in sorption capacity as we move toward 100% black carbon. From these results we concluded that iron oxides in the clay particles in the soils were the dominant source of arsenic sorptivity, but black carbon was the dominant source of chromium sorptivity. Thus, having more black carbon in a sedimentary deposit will significantly slow a plume of chromium passing through it, but it will not slow a plume of arsenic. The charge of the particles being sorbed is key to predicting the effect of increased black carbon.

From a management perspective, the main result of this research is that black carbon naturally erodes from a burned area in a window of high erosion activity that typically lasts at least 3 years following a fire, but probably no more than 10 years. Any black carbon that is retained past that window may remain in the soils for decades, providing contaminant sequestration benefits and also sequestering carbon from the atmosphere. If post-fire erosion can be reduced by encouraging rapid vegetation regrowth then additional black carbon can be retained.
